required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Co-administration of Propofol and Remifentanil for Lumbar Puncture in Children
clinical_study.official_title: Co-administration of Propofol and Remifentanil for Lumbar Puncture in Children: Evaluation of Two Dose Combinations

brief_summary.textblock: The objective of this study is to compare intraoperative and recovery parameters in patients who receive two different dose combinations of propofol and remifentanil in patients undergoing a lumbar puncture.

detailed_description.textblock: Lumbar punctures (LP) are performed in approximately one thousand oncology patients per year at the Hospital for Sick Children. In a previous study, we determined the optimal dose of remifentanil which provides effective anesthesia with little or no movement during LP in children. The present study will determine the optimal dose combination of propofol and remifentanil to keep patients comfortable and still during the procedure while decreasing the incidence of side effects and allows for shorter recovery times and earlier discharge from the recovery room.

primary_outcome.time_frame: This outcome was measured for the duration of the procedure (lumbar puncture).

primary_outcome.measure: Duration of Postoperative Recovery (Time to Spontaneous Eye Opening, Verbalization, Purposeful Movement).
primary_outcome.time_frame: This outcome was measured for the duration of the recovery phase.

secondary_outcome.measure: Incidence of Adverse Events and Clinically Significant Changes in Routine Vital Signs as Measured by Electrocardiogram, Non-invasive Blood Pressure, and Pulse Oximeter.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: This outcome was measured for the duration of the procedure (lumbar puncture).

intervention.description: Patients in this arm of the study will receive 2.0 mg/kg propofol + 1.5 ug/kg remifentanil. An anesthesiologist will inject propofol mixed with lidocaine, followed immediately by remifentanil, diluted with 0.9% saline to a volume of 3 ml and administered as a bolus.

Patients in this arm of the study will receive 4.0 mg/kg propofol + 0.5 ug/kg remifentanil. An anesthesiologist will inject propofol mixed with lidocaine, followed immediately by remifentanil, diluted with 0.9% saline to a volume of 3 ml and administered as a bolus.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Clinical diagnosis of a hemato-oncological disorder
- Scheduled to undergo a lumbar puncture
- Aged 3-12 years
- Unpremedicated
Exclusion Criteria:
- children who are known or suspected to be difficult to ventilate by face mask
- children who are deemed medically unfit to receive either of the two study medications
- children who are obese (weight for height > 95th percentile)
- children who do not have an indwelling intravenous line

overall_official.affiliation: The Hospital for Sick Children, Toronto Canada

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
